Title: Alexander Glazunov - Violin Concerto: Stokowski and Marcovici with the LSO in 1972
Description:
Leopold Stokowski appeared with the London Symphony Orchestra on two successive evenings in June 1972 to celebrate the sixtieth anniversary of his first conducting engagement with the orchestra in 1912. The second of these concerts at the Royal Albert Hall was recorded by Decca for their Phase Four series; this performance of the Glazunov concerto by Silvia Marcovici was given the previous evening at the Festival Hall.

Title: Bach Magnificat Mahler 2 Philadelphia Stokowski Nov 1967 Live
Beethoven 'Prometheus' Overture - Stokowski conducts
Description:
Stokowski often conducted Beethoven in his long career but this is the only extant performance of the great maestro conducting the Overture to 'The Creatures of Prometheus.'  It comes from an American Symphony concert given in 1971 and commences an all-Beethoven CD issued by 'CRQ Editions' on which Stokowski also conducts the Triple Concerto and 2nd Symphony (CRQ CD250).
NOTE: although the magazine 'Classical Recordings Quarterly' was wound down a while ago, it's sister website 'CRQ Editions' still issues historic recordings to order. This 'Prometheus' Overture comes from a Stokowski / Beethoven CD Series of many 'live' performances that include works he never recorded commercially.

Title: Cowell Koto Cto Eto Wagner Meistersinger Philadelphia Stokowski Dec 1964 Live
Description: Leopold Stokowski guest conducts the Philadelphia Orchestra in the World Premiere of Cowell’s Koto Concerto No. 1, with Kimio Eto, the famous blind Koto player, as soloist, and then the Act III prelude to Wagner’s Meistersinger and two other familiar Act III bits (Dance of the Apprentices and Procession of the Meistersingers). A Koto Concerto was Eto’s idea, and he quickly prevailed upon Cowell to write it. Cowell, an eclectic composer, was championed by Stokowski, Ormandy, and Koussevitsky. Since his death in 1965, his music (and his life story, which included a term of imprisonment for gay sex) have largely been forgotten. Cowell was present at this premiere, which would travel down to Washington, DC and then Carnegie Hall in the days following this concert, a frequent route for the orchestra.  The Wagner was commercially recorded multiple times by Philadelphia beginning in the early 1930s, under Stokowski and Ormandy for Victor, Columbia, and RCA, and under Thielemann for DG (in 1997).

Title: Gabrieli Vivaldi Mozart Philadelphia Stokowski Feb 1964 Live
Description: Philadelphia’s first chair virtuosi on parade. Interesting to note that none of the principals is a Stokowski holdover; each was hired by Ormandy, yet Stokowski’s program’s stated purpose is to exhibit their virtuosity. Certainly sheds some doubt on the mythology of friction between Stokie and EO. Make sure to hear another Gabrieli canzon from 1972 under Ozawa’s baton, separately posted on this channel. And for an awe-inspiring celebration of both Gabrieli and the state of leading American orchestras, find the Columbia/Sony album “The Antiphonal Music of Gabrieli,” recorded in 1968 in Philadelphia with Chicago and Cleveland’s brass combining with Philadelphia’s. Although Bill Smith doesn’t mention it, the Vivaldi is almost certainly Stokowski’s own arrangement previously commercially recorded in 1934 on Victor. It is nice to hear the Mozart in more natural stereo sound than the tinny 1957 commercial recording on Columbia with these same forces, even with Mason Jones breaking some notes in the first movement. The second half of this pension fund concert is the Shostakovich 5, also separately uploaded into this channel.

Title: Glazunov: Violin Concerto - Silvia Marcovici, violin; Stokowski conducts the LSO
Description: In 1972, Stokowski celebrated his 90th birthday and also the 60th Anniversary of his debut with the London Symphony Orchestra. To mark these two events, he conducted the LSO at the Royal Festival Hall in the same programme that they'd played in 1912. It included the Glazunov Violin Concerto which in 1912 had been played by Efrem Zimbalist. For the 1972 anniversary repeat it was performed by Silvia Marcovici. This is the only extant film of Leopold Stokowski conducting a violin concerto.

Title: Kurt Leimer: Piano Concerto No. 2 - Stokowski conducts
Description:
Leopold Stokowski conducted hundreds of works only once in his long and illustrious career and here is one of them. German-born Kurt Leimer (1920-1974) was a concert pianist who also combined composing with teaching. He persuaded several great conductors to accompany him in his own works, including Herbert von Karajan for a recording with the Philharmonia Orchestra of his Piano Concerto for the Left Hand. Stokowski also conducted the Symphony of the Air for another Leimer recording, his Piano Concerto No. 4.
 
Here we see the Maestro and the composer together in a 1968 Swiss-Italian TV studio performance of Leimer's 2nd Piano Concerto. A CD release of the soundtrack was met with comments on its references to Rachmaninoff, Prokofiev, Gershwin and others, so some listeners might find the work a bit of a mish-mash. It seems hardly likely that it will ever be taken into the general piano concerto repertoire, so it is uploaded here for its rarity value. It is also a tribute to Stokowski's willingness to conduct from time to time something new, unfamiliar and not quite top-drawer!

Title: Live - Jorge Bolet and Leopold Stokowski - Prokofiev Piano Concerto No.2  (1971)
Description:
I generally limit my postings to vinyl, but I am making an exception today.  For some years I have had a bootleg-ish CD with two performances of Jorge Bolet that were recorded by persons in the audience at his concerts.  (I have read that Bolet actually encouraged patrons to make recordings for themselves.)  The quality of these recordings was very poor, and in fact the second recording (a Brahms piece) is unlistenable as the batteries were running low on the tape player causing massive wow and flutter.

All I know about this recording is that it was stated on the CD hat it was Jorge Bolet with Leopold Stokowski conducting the American Symphony Orchestra.  The recording is ostensibly from 1971.   There is little doubt this is Jorge Bolet.   It is a live recording and you will hear audience noise and at one point a siren outside outside the venue can be heard!

I have done my best to try to make the performance more listenable.   This included some compromises, such as trying to give greater emphasis to the piano so that it could be heard over the orchestra.  In any case, it is chance to hear Bolet play this live - and adds to the two other studio recordings he made of this piece (both posted on my channel.)

Finally - please note that like the other Bolet performances he cuts the cadenza short by 10 measures.   So, I hope listeners won't dwell on this.

Description:

I. Allegro maestroso

Maria Lucia Godoy, soprano

Conducted by Leopold STOKOWSKI
Live, Philadelphia, 9 november 1967 
_
O Röschen rot,
Der Mensch liegt in größter Not,
Der Mensch liegt in größter Pein,
Je lieber möcht' ich im Himmel sein.
Da kam ich auf einem breiten Weg,
Da kam ein Engelein und wollt' mich abweisen.
Ach nein, ich ließ mich nicht abweisen!
Ich bin von Gott und will wieder zu Gott,
Der liebe Gott wird mir ein Lichtchen geben,
Wird leuchten mir bis in das ewig selig' Leben!
_
texte en français: http://www.recmusic.org/lieder/get_te...
text in English: http://www.recmusic.org/lieder/get_te...

Chor und Sopran:
 Aufersteh'n, ja aufersteh'n wirst du,
 Mein Staub, nach kurzer Ruh!
 Unsterblich Leben
 Wird, der dich rief, dir geben.
 Wieder aufzublüh'n, wirst du gesät!
 Der Herr der Ernte geht
 Und sammelt Garben
 Uns ein, die starben!

Alt solo:
 O glaube, mein Herz, o glaube:
 Es geht dir nichts verloren!
 Dein ist, ja dein, was du gesehnt,
 Dein, was du geliebt, was du gestritten!

Sopran solo:
 O glaube: Du wardst nicht umsonst geboren!
 Hast nicht umsonst gelebt, gelitten!

Chor und Alt:
 Was entstanden ist, das muß vergehen!
 Was vergangen, auferstehen!
 Hör auf zu beben!
 Bereite dich zu leben!

Sopran und Alt solo:
 O Schmerz! Du Alldurchdringer!
 Dir bin ich entrungen.
 O Tod! Du Allbezwinger!
 Nun bist du bezwungen!
 Mit Flügeln, die ich mir errungen,
 In heißem Liebesstreben
 Werd ich entschweben
 Zum Licht, zu dem kein Aug' gedrungen!

Chor:
 Mit Flügeln, die ich mir errungen,
 Werd ich entschweben!
 Sterben werd' ich, um zu leben!
 Aufersteh'n, ja aufersteh'n wirst du,
 Mein Herz, in einem Nu!
 Was du geschlagen,
 Zu Gott wird es dich tragen!
_

Title: Mussorgsky-Stokowski 'Pictures at an Exhibition' - UK Premiere - Proms 1963
Description:
Leopold Stokowski was the first major foreign conductor to appear at the London 'Proms' concerts following a decision to make them more 'international.' Hitherto they had been mainly conducted by such British musicians as Sir Henry Wood and his successor Sir Malcolm Sargent but from 1963 onwards more and more non-British conductors have taken part.

For his Proms debut at the Royal Albert Hall, with the BBCSO on 23 July 1963, Stokowski was asked to conclude the concert with his own orchestration of Mussorgsky's 'Pictures at an Exhibition' in its UK Premiere. The programme also included Britten's 'Variations and Fugue on a Theme of Purcell' and Beethoven's 7th Symphony, both of which have been released on CD. 

Stokowski's version of 'Pictures at an Exhibition' omits the two French locations ('Limoges' and 'Tuileries') as he felt the work as whole should be as 'Slavic' as possible. The sequence is as follows:

Promenade 00:00
Gnomus 01:48
Promenade 03:57
The Old Castle 05:07
Bydlo (A Polish Ox Wagon) 08:22
Promenade 10:10
Ballet of Unhatched Chickens 11:00
Samuel Goldenberg and Schmuyle 12:12
Catacombs 14:40
The Hut on Fowl's Legs (Baba-Yaga) 18:16
The Great Gate of Kiev 20:52

The stereo recording of the broadcast comes from a 'Music and Arts' release (CD-765) to whom all due acknowledgements are made.

Title: Pension Fund Concert Ravel Revueltas etc Philadelphia Stokowski Dec 1962 Live
Description: Leopold Stokowski conducts rousing renditions of Ravel's Alborada del Gracioso, Revueltas's Sensemaya, selected portions of Stravinsky’s Petrouchka suite, Purcell's Trumpet Voluntary (later attributed to Jeremiah Clark instead of Purcell, and here in a more scaled down arrangement than in the Ormandy-conducted pension fund concert elsewhere on this channel), Morton Gould's Guaracha from the third movement of his Latin-American Symphonette, Stokowski's own over-the-top arrangement of Rachmaninoff's Prelude No. 2 in C#min, and as a final farewell to the audience the final movement of Haydn's Symphony No. 45 ("Farewell").  Program notes spoken by assistant conductor Bill Smith. The first half of this pension fund concert (Wagner and Beethoven) is available elsewhere on this channel.

Title: Rachmaninoff Paganini Starr Philadelphia Stokowski Jan 1963 Live
Description: Radio (WFLN) broadcast of the Philadelphia Orchestra playing Rachmaninoff's Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini, live in a gala concert in January of 1963.  Leopold Stokowski conducts, with soloist Susan Starr (a native Philadelphian, Tchaikovsky Competition medalist, and frequent soloist with the orchestra under Ormandy, and whose father, Isadore Schwartz, was a second violinist in the orchestra). Title: Schelomo: Shapiro - Stokowski (LIVE!)
Description:
Schelomo: live performance, Carnegie Hall (c.1966): Harvey Shapiro, 'cello; Leopold Stokowski, conductor; American Symphony Orchestra
Schelomo: Rhapsodie Hébraïque for Violoncello and Orchestra, by Ernest Bloch (July 24, 1880 -- July 15, 1959) was the final work of the composer's  "Jewish Cycle." Composed 1915 -- 1916 Schelomo was premiered May 13, 1917 by 'cellist Hans Kindler, Artur Bodanzky conductor, Carnegie Hall. Harvey Shapiro, 'cellist (June 22, 1911 -- October 25, 2007) was a student of Willem Willeke (1879 -- 1950), the major 'cello teacher at the Institute of Musical Art New York, which merged with the Juilliard School in 1926. Violinist Joachim took the young Willeke to meet Brahms, and the three of them played the composer's chamber music. Willeke studied the Brahms 'cello works with the composer, played with numerous other major composers of the latter 19th Century, including Grieg and Richard Strauss and was the dedicatee of their Sonatas for Violoncello and Piano. Willeke's vast heritage was transplanted to his student Harvey Shapiro, who from age 60 to the end of his life at age 96 became one of the most important teachers at the Juilliard School in New York. In his younger years Shapiro was a member of the NBC Symphony under Arturo Toscanini. Along with his colleagues from the NBC, violinists Oscar Shumsky and Josef Gingold, and violist William Primrose, they formed the Primrose Quartet, acknowledged as one of the finest quartets of the 20th Century.
Read more about 'cellist/teacher Harvey Shapiro here: http://www.jameskreger.com/article7.htm

Title: Shostakovich 5 Philadelphia Stokowski Feb 1964 Live
Description: Concluding work of pension fund concert. (The first half, showpieces to demonstrate the first desk virtuosity Philly boasted, is separately posted in this channel, consisting of Gabrieli, Vivaldi, and Mozart.) Bill Smith reminds us that Stokowski was the first to conduct this symphony in Philadelphia. He could have added that Stokowski and Philadelphia were the first to record it in the Unites States, in April of 1939 on Victor, the world’s second commercial recording and the first American one. This is a straightforward performance, in beautiful sound, largely free of Stokowski mannerisms. He does speed up tempo for excitement periodically, and the fourth movement is quite brisk, requiring him to slow things down once or twice to ensure articulation in passages. But ensemble remains perfect throughout. A couple of horn fluffs in the second movement and a single trumpet crack in the fourth are the only blemishes.

Title: Stokowski conducts Beethoven "Eroica" Symphony - LSO 'live' (1974)
Description: Leopold Stokowski conducted Beethoven's "Eroica" Symphony for the first time in 1910 with the Cincinnati Orchestra. On 10 February 1974, in the Royal Albert Hall, he conducted his last concert performance of the work at the age of 91 with the London Symphony Orchestra, with whom he recorded it a few weeks later. That concert performance was not broadcast, so what is played here is an 'in the house' stereo cassette recording. It is clearly not up to broadcasting standards but the vitality of the great nonagenarian's performance, which received much critical acclaim, nevertheless makes it fully deserving of its preservation here. Indeed, one critic wrote that it was "very far from the arthritic routine run-through you might expect from a veteran conductor," adding that it was "one of the quickest accounts of the whole work on record ... It had tremendous impetus and enough vigour for a conductor half Stokowski's age." The Maestro was reported to have said after the concert: "I didn't want it to drag"!

Title: Stokowski conducts Brahms-Sargent 'Academic Festival' Overture with Choral Finale
Description: In 1973, the 91-year-old Leopold Stokowski conducted the London Philharmonic Orchestra & Chorus in a 'Brahms and Tchaikovsky Favourites' concert in the Royal Albert Hall. It began with the 'Academic Festival' Overture to which Sir Malcolm Sargent had added his own choral finale and which was adopted by the conductor. The concert was not broadcast but was surreptitiously taped 'in the hall', so the sound quality is not of the best. However, the performance is unique as far as Stokowski's repertoire is concerned, so is duly presented here.

Title: Stokowski conducts Schubert "Unfinished" Symphony - All-American Youth Orchestra (1941)
Description:
Leopold Stokowski conducted a great many recording premieres during his 60 years as an illustrious 20th Century maestro and Schubert's "Unfinished" Symphony was one of them. In 1924 he and the Philadelphia Orchestra made the first American recording of the work on acoustic 78s in front of an enormous wooden horn. Four years later, with the introduction of microphones, they re-recorded it in the new electrical method.

After a quarter of a century in Philadelphia, Stokowski decided it was time to move on and in 1940 he created the All-American Youth Orchestra. He made a number of 78s with them for Coliumbia, including a remake of the Schubert "Unfinished." He was to record it for the last time in 1969, at the age of 87, with the London Philharmonic in "Phase 4 Stereo." However, his 1941 recording with its youthful band of American players receives a particularly dramatic performance, as will be heard in this upload.

Schubert started the work in 1822 but left it incomplete, causing much speculation as to his reasons. These have never been resolved but the two-movement work has nevertheless become one of the most popular symphonies in the classical orchestral repertoire.

(I) Allegro moderato
(II) Andante con moto

From 'Cala Records' CACD0520.

Title: Stokowski conducts Tchaikovsky 'Italian Caprice' - London Philharmonic (1973 'live')
Description: Leopold Stokowski conducted numerous "premieres" in the days of 78s and in 1929 he made the first American recording of Tchaikovsky's "Capriccio Italien" with the Philadelphia Orchestra. Forty-four years later, at the age of 91, he gave his last public performance of the work with the London Philharmonic in the Royal Albert Hall. As will be heard, even at that great age, the now very frail conductor had lost none of his vitality. The concert date was 4th November 1973 and although it was not broadcast, the performance was privately taped 'in the hall,' so is NOT of high audio quality! ... Nevertheless it remains a treasurable memento of an exciting occasion and is especially notable for Stokowski's 'rubato' in the slower passages!

Title: Tchaikovsky "1812 Overture" - Stokowski conducts at the Royal Albert Hall
Description: Leopold Stokowski conducted a spectacular all-Russian concert in London's Royal Albert Hall on 15 June 1969 from which this "1812 Overture" comes. It was played by the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra and the Band of the Grenadier Guards. (A 'BBC Legends' CD.)

Title: Tchaikovsky "Romeo and Juliet" - Stokowski conducts
Description: In 1968, during one of his European tours, Stokowski visited Lugano and recorded a studio concert for Swiss-Italian Television. One of the items was Tchaikovsky's "Romeo and Juliet" Overture. This had run to three different editions, the second and third of which were published, due to the composer's many revisions. In 'The Life and Letters of Tchaikovsky' by his brother Modest, it was revealed that Balakirev objected to the loud accentuated chords at the end of the work on the grounds that they "contradicted the meaning of the play" and were "inartistic." According to Modest, Tchaikovsky then supplied a quiet ending at Balakirev's suggestion, though it was never published. Stokowski clearly knew of Balakirev's comments and agreed with them, since he supplied an ending of his own which omitted those loud "inartistic" chords. It is that version we hear in this Swiss-Italian Radio Orchestra performance.

Title: Tchaikovsky 'Eugene Onegin' Polonaise - Stokowski conducts
Description: Leopold Stokowski returned to England at the age of 90 in 1972 and remained busily active in the recording studio and concert hall. One of his concerts, given in the Royal Albert Hall in 1973 with the London Philharmonic, consisted of "Brahms and Tchaikovsky Favourites." It concluded with the dazzling encore heard here and showed that the great maestro had lost none of his vitality. Note that it has been issued on CRQ Editions CRQ CD321 along with other splendid Stokowski 'live' performances (crqeditions.co.uk).
